title: 113_s1158
content:
The Act is titled the "National Park Service 100th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act". Congress established the National Park Service in 1916 to administer national parks and monuments, which has since grown to over 395 units with 84 million acres of land. The Service's responsibilities now include managing historic and scenic trails, wild and scenic rivers, and recognizing significant historic resources in the United States. The National Park Service was established in 1916 to manage national parks and monuments, now overseeing over 395 units with 84 million acres of land. Its responsibilities include managing historic and scenic trails, wild and scenic rivers, and recognizing significant historic resources in the United States through various programs and grants. The core mission of the National Park Service is to conserve natural and historic objects for future generations. The 100th anniversary of the National Park Service in 2016 will celebrate a century of American vision in preserving special places for future generations. Coins commemorating this milestone will have national and international significance. The National Park Service was established in 1916 to protect natural and cultural resources in the United States. A surcharge on commemorative coins will help finance the needs of the parks and programs, ensuring these resources endure for future generations. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The coins minted under this Act will have a diameter of 1.205 inches and be minted to the specifications for half dollar clad coins. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted under this Act will follow specifications for half dollar clad coins and have a diameter of 1.205 inches. The design of the coins minted under this Act for the 100th anniversary of the National Park Service will include inscriptions of the face value, year 2016, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Park Service, National Park Foundation, Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Coins minted under this Act for the 100th anniversary of the National Park Service will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from January 1, 2016, to December 31, 2016. The Secretary is authorized to sell these coins during this period. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount.

SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins minted under this Act shall include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half dollar coin. Surcharges received by the Secretary will be promptly paid to the National Park Foundation for projects that preserve and protect resources under the National Park Service's stewardship. Surcharges cannot be used for land acquisition. The National Park Foundation is subject to audit requirements for amounts received under this Act. No surcharge can be included if it exceeds the commemorative coin program issuance limitation. The Secretary may issue guidance for this limitation.
